Population: A group of patients eligible for antiretroviral therapy based on the presence of clinical illness and/or a CD4 cell count of <200 cells/microliter.
Compared strategies: Current practice (symptom screening, sputum smear microscopy, and chest radiography); culture as recommended by WHO guidelines (2007); the WHO algorithm as updated in 2011 and is based on the Xpert MTB/RIF test.
ICER: culture: $60,430/death averted; Xpert: dominated
Reporting of uncertainty: Tornado diagram of DSA, CEAC
Main findings: A diagnostic approach that includes culture was most effective at averting early deaths, but it was not the least costly approach compared with other algorithms considered. The algorithm with Xpert cost less and was more effective in reducing early mortality compared with the current practice.

Population: Patients visiting an eye centre with signs suggestive of TB uveitis
Compared strategies: TST only; Interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) following a positive TST;  IGRA only; TST and IGRA simultaneously
ICER: TSt: $3611/QALY; IGRA: dominated; TST and IGRA: 11506/QALY (using TST followed by IGRA as reference)
Reporting of uncertainty: Table of DSA, Tornado diagram of DSA, Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied), CEAC
Main findings: In the context of our study population, while recognising the difficulties of diagnosing TB uveitis, our results suggest that the dual-test strategy of performing TST and IGRA simultaneously appears to be the most cost-effective strategy relative to the other strategies.

Population: Patients with suspected, uncomplicated, community-acquired, acute bacterial sinusitis who had had symptoms for less than 4 weeks and who had not had recurrent sinusitis
Compared strategies: No patients given antibiotic treatment; all patients given empirical amoxicillin treatment; patients given amoxicillin based on the results of a set of clinical criteria; patients given amoxicillin based on the results of sinus radiography (plain film x-ray)
Included treatment: 10-day course of amoxicillin, 250 mg 3 times a day.
ICER: 34.0 costs/symptom free day (in a mild scenario)
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA), Table of DSA, Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied)
Main findings: The best strategy for diagnosing and treating acute sinusitis depends in part on the prevalence of the bacterial sinusitis (or the likelihood that a given patient actually has the disease)

Population: All the hospitalized patients between the years 2011 and 2015
Compared strategies: Treatment for all; no treatment; treatment based on the rapid test for a streptococcal antigen; treatment based on the culture test result; treatment based on RTA plus culture; treatment based on the RTA result, and in the case of a negative result, culturing.
ICER: RTA + culture: 0.007564; RTA: 0.048541; Culture: 0.049706 (unit: costs /quality-adjusted life day)
Reporting of uncertainty: Tornado diagram of DSA
Main findings: The most effective mean observed quality‑adjusted life days was the simultaneous diagnostic treatment of RTA and culture; the highest amount of saving (monetary cost) was detected in RTA before treatment.

Population: Patients with CAP, less than 65 years old, without hospital admission criteria; Patients with AECB due to respiratory infection.
Compared strategies: Simple chest x-ray and a blood count; empirical antibiotics
Included treatment: Macrolides (erythromycin, clarithromycin, azithromycin, roxithromycin); Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, ofloxacin); Cephalosporins (cefuroxime, ceftriaxone); Betalactam (penicillin, amoxicillin, amoxicillin clavulanic acid).
Clinical outcomes: Clinical effectiveness of the first antibiotic option
Time horizon: from the moment the treatment started in primary care to the final healing or clinical failure after a third antibiotic option prescribed in hospital administration
ICER: Patients with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP): Betalactam antibiotic treatment is the most cost-effective strategy. Hospitalization, directly related to the success rate of the first empirical antibiotic treatment, is the main driver of the final average cost per patient, rating from 50% to 70% of total cost. Acquisition costs of the first empirical antibiotic treatment represents just a small fraction of the total costs (between 2% and 13%)
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA)
Main findings: The model indicates that acquisition costs of the initial empirical antibiotic represent a small fraction of total treatment costs in patients with lower respiratory tract infections acquired in the community

Setting: A centre dedicated to the diagnosis and treatment of TB
Population: All the patients diagnosed with MDR-TB
Compared strategies: LPA-based diagnostic algorithm (smear positive (SSm+) and for smear negative(SSm-) culture confirmed TB patients by Bactec MGIT or LJ; conventional culture-based algorithm (LJ–for SSm- and SSm+ patients and BacTAlert–for SSm+patients).
ICER: SSm+ LPA-based diagnostics reducuded the costs by 4.5 compared to LJ and by 2.5 times compared to BacTAlert liquid culture
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA)
Main findings: TB diagnostic algorithms incorporating LPA method proved to be both more clinically effective and less expensive due to reduction in the number of hospital days to the correct MDR-TB diagnosis and treatment initiation

Population: Patients hospitalized with community-acquired pneumonia in the internal medicin department
Compared strategies: Current practice; Inquaro, a computer system to aid in diagnosing community-acquired pneumonia patients
Included treatment: Levofloxacin, clarithromycin, ampicillin/sulbactam; ceftriaxon; erythomycin; ampicillin; cefazolin; doxycyclin
Model type: Differences are calculated using T tests
Clinical outcomes: Days with symptoms, days with antibiotics, hospital length of stay, application time
ICER: No incremental cost-effectiveness outcomes reported, only individual costs (microbiology: -11.77; imaging procedures: 8.32; antibiotic costs: -114.04; application costs: -100.41) and individual effects (application time (h): -5.4; days with symptoms: -3.5; days with antibiotics: -3; hospital length-of-stay (days): -3)
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA)
Main findings: Improvements were found for the patients (fewer infusions, faster symptom resolution and a shorted length-of-stay)

Population: TB-suspected patients (cough of at least 2 weeks)
Compared strategies: Bleach smear (B) and direct smear (D) (under microscope) in various combinations and orders: D1+D2; B1; B1+B2; D1+B1; B1+D2; D1+B2; D1+B1+D2; D1+D2+B2; D1+B1+B2; B1+D2+B2
ICER: B1+B2: €50; D1+B1: €276; : €71; D1+B1+D2, D1+B2, B1+D2, D1+D2+B2, D1+B1+B2, B1+D2+B2: dominated, measure of effectiveness: costs / proportion of smear-positive patients detected among the total number of PTB suspects (using D1+D2 and B1 as references)
Reporting of uncertainty: Table of DSA
Main findings: Considering all potential combinations of direct smear and smear after overnight NaOCl sedimentation, the approaches based on the single examination of the first concentrated specimen or based on the examination of two concentrated specimens were the most cost-effective: B1 due to its low cost, and B1+B2 dueto its effectiveness and low ICER compared to B1.

Population: Eligible patients were aged 18 years or older, consulting with their GP with a new episode of acute cough of up to 28 days and caused by an lower respiratory tract infections (LRTIs) in the GPs view
Compared strategies: GPs managed patients in the usual care group with the availability of the Dutch College of GPs guidelines for acute cough: GP use of CRP; GP communication skills training; GP use of CRP and GP communication skills training
ICER: The ICER of GP use of CRP versus usual care was €5.79 and for GP use of both CRP and Communication versus usual care €4.15. Communication was superior to usual care costs or savings /antibiotic prescription saved
Reporting of uncertainty: Probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA)
Main findings: The interventions are cost-effective in any combination (yielding NMB at no willingness-to pay), taking into account GPs’ preferences where at least 15% of GPs chose to implementthe communication skills training.

Population: Inpatients placed in airborne infection isolation for presumptive pulmonary TB.
Compared strategies: 1 Xpert on an unconcentrated sputum sample; 1 Xpert on a concentrated sample; 2 Xperts on concentrated sputum samples; 2 smears; and 3 smears
ICER: XPERT 2 concentrated: $2826682/accurately diagnosed case; 2 smears: $-320893/accurately diagnosed case; 3 smears: $-363987/accurately diagnosed case (reference 1 Xpert concentrated and unconcentrated, which are expected to have equal performance)
Reporting of uncertainty: Tornado diagram of DSA, Two-way sensitivity analysis graph, Probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA), CE plane, CEAC
Main findings: The present study supports analyses suggesting that Xpert implementation in the United States is cost-effective and can reduce AII duration. .A single-Xpert strategy was cost-saving in a variety of sensitivity analyses, suggesting that replacement of 3 AFB smears with Xpert to determine the need for AII would result in cost savings for most US hospitals.

Population: Patients presenting with Acute sinusitis in primary care
Compared strategies: Wait and see; selective prescription; empirical antibiotics; ultrasound assessment; radiographic assessment
ICER: Clinical assessment: DFL 515.59; Ultrasound assessment: DFL 5745.38; Radiographic assessment: DFL 3164.98; Antibiotics: DFL 881.67 costs or savings /patient
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA), Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied), Two-way sensitivity analysis graph
Main findings: The costs for curing one additional patient were DFL516 when antibiotics were selectively prescribed and DFL882 when antibiotics were prescribed immediately

Population: Patients who consulted for community-acquired pneumonia in emergency departments
Compared strategies: Pneumococcal urinary antigen test; usual care
Included treatment: Antimicrobial treatment (penicillin A if Streptococcus pneumoniae), broad-spectrum antibiotics without microbiological identification
ICER: As only 7 PUA tests led to appropriate antimicrobial modification, we deemed that the potential cost savings, if the test had not been used, would have been 26,244 € during 3 years, that is 8748 € per year.
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA)
Main findings: The test should be used only for patients with probable CAP

Population: Patients presenting  with symptoms of an acute respiratory infection at risk or potentially having influenza-related complications.
Compared strategies: Treat none; treat based on provider judgement; treat based on a PCR-based rapid test; treat all
Included treatment: Antiviral treatment: oseltamivir, zanamivir; antibiotics: amoxicillin/expensive antibiotics
ICER: PCR: $1389/QALY; treat all: $6246/QALY; treat none: dominated (all compared to provider judgement)
Reporting of uncertainty: Tornado diagram of DSA, CEAC
Main findings: Assuming a $50,000 per quality-adjusted life-year willingness-to-pay threshold, the most cost-effective treatment option is treatment according to provider judgment from 0% to 3% prevalence, treatment according to a PCR-based rapid influenza test from 3% to 7% prevalence, and treating all at greater than 7% prevalence.

Population: HIV-infected adults with suspected central nervous system infections
Compared strategies: Comprehensive testing; stepwise testing; minimalist testing
Included treatment: 2g ceftriaxone intramuscularly once for meningococcal meningitis; five days of ceftriaxone for pneumococcal meningitis.
ICER: 133 per additional correct diagnosis
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA)
Main findings: Through strategically choosing the order and type of testing coupled with disease prevalence rates, algorithms can deliver more care more efficiently.

Population: Patients between the ages of 2 and 14 years who consult with a primary care physician due to AP symptoms.
Compared strategies: Treat all; clinical scoring; rapid testing; culture; rapid test + culture; clinical scoring + rapid test.
Clinical outcomes: Proportion of patients cured without complications from the disease or from any adverse reaction to treatment with penicillin
ICER: Only rapid test: 51.22; clinical scoring + rapid test: 50.72 (Costs per patient cured without complications and no adverse reaction to penicillin)
Reporting of uncertainty: Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied), Two-way sensitivity analysis graph
Main findings: The “clinical scoring + rapid test” strategy was the most cost-effective of the six strategies analysed

Population: Patients admitted  with suspected ILI
Compared strategies: PCR; diagnosis with influenza RDT + clinical data
ICER: $12.60 saved each suspected case
Reporting of uncertainty: Fagan nomogram
Main findings: The use of PR as an aid in the diagnosis of H1N1 influenza increases certainty and reduces the average cost per suspect and infected patient.

Population: Ambulatory HIV-infected patients in South Africa
Compared strategies: 33 diagnostic options, involving combinations of specimen collection methods (oral washes induced and expectorated sputum and bronchoalveolar lavage); PCR or clinical diagnosis with chest x-ray alone
Included treatment: Treatment costs are based on a single, 21-day regimen with oral CTX
Clinical outcomes: Life years, Proportion of ill patients successfully treated
ICER: At 50% disease prevalence, diagnostic procedures involving expectorated sputum with any PCR method, or induced sputum with nested or real-time PCR, were all highly cost-effective, successfully treating 77–90% of patients at $26–51 per life-year gained.
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA)
Main findings: Three metrics are relevant: proportion of PCP patients successfully treated, proportion of well persons unnecessarily treated, and the total diagnostic and treatment cost per life-year gained.

Population: Patients with suspected TB
Compared strategies: Routine TB diagnosis; XPERT
ICER: €2960/QALY
Reporting of uncertainty: Table of DSA, Tornado diagram of DSA, Probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA), CEAC
Main findings: The implementation of a molecular microbiological technique in the diagnosis of tuberculosisis extremely cost-effective compared to the usual method. Its introduction into the routine diagnostic procedure could lead to an improvement in quality care for patients, given that it would avoid both unnecessary hospitalisations and treatments, and reflected in economic savings to the hospital.

Population: Adults with symptoms of acute respiratory tract infection (ARTI) for >12 h where the antibiotic decision is unclear
Compared strategies: Current standard of care; antibiotic prescribing conditional on POC CRP testing.
Included treatment: Amoxicillin 500 mg three times daily for 7 days.
ICER: In patients with symptoms of ARTI and based on routine practice, the ICERs of CRP testing were £19,705 per quality-adjusted-life-year (QALY) gained and £16.07 per antibiotic prescription avoided
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA), Table of DSA, Probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA), Cost-effectiveness plane of PSA, Cost-effectiveness acceptability curve(s)
Main findings: The model suggests that as implemented in routine primary care (for all adults with symptoms of ARTI for >12 hours where the antibiotic decision unclear) POC CRP testing is borderline cost-effective.

Population: Cohorts of 100 hypothetical patients with RTI
Compared strategies: Current GP practice; Three strategies of CRP testing: 1) GP plus CRP; 2) Practice nurse plus CRP; 3) GP plus CRP and communicating training
Included treatment: Antibiotics at index consultation, antibiotics within 28 days of index, atibotics for subsequent incidents of RTIs after 28 days
Clinical outcomes: QALYs, number of antibiotics prescribed and the number of RTIs over 3 years
Discount rate: economic: 3.5% for costs and benefits (QALYs multiplied by the willingness to pay; health: NA
ICER: The two strategies result in 0.13 additional QALYs per 100 patients and costs 42 pounds less per 100 patients  for the GP plus CRP strategy and 680 pounds less for the nurse plus CRP strategy
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA), Probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA), Cost-effectiveness plane of PSA, Cost-effectiveness acceptability curve(s)
Main findings: Over a 3-year time horizon, GP plus CRP test and nurse plus CRP test have a higher net monetary benefits than current practice. The additional costs of the test is outwighted by cost savings and QALY increment associated with a reduction in infections in the long run.

Population: Patients with (clinically) suspected TB
Compared strategies: Sputum smear microscopy alone; TBDx automated microscopy alone; TBDx automated microscopy,with confirmation of low positive results by Xpert MTB/RIF; TBDx automated microscopy, with confirmation of all positive results by Xpert MTB/RIF; Xpert MTB/RIF performed on all specimens
Included treatment: Non-specified TB therapy (both drug-susceptible and drug-resistant)
Discount rate: economic: 3% was used to annualized costs of equipment (no discount rate for outcomes); health: NA
ICER: Main outcome reported: $1280 per incremental TB diagnosis, TBDx automated microscopy
Reporting of uncertainty: Table of DSA, Tornado diagram of DSA, Uncertainty ranges (95%) around results
Main findings: In settings where universal XpertMTB/RIF is affordable, and health systems are willing to pay at least $1927 per incremental TB diagnosis made, universal Xpert is generally preferred.

Population: Patients with presumptive TB - different algorithms for patients with and without HIV.
Compared strategies: Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) microscopy; LED fluorescence microscopy; same-day LED fluorescence microscopy; full Xpert rollout; Xpert for known HIV-+ cases; Xpert for HIV-+ cases with additional HIV screening; Xpert for smear-negative and known HIV-+ cases; Xpert for smear-negative and HIV-+ cases with additional HIV testing
Included treatment: Standard regimen; retreatment regimen; resistant TB regimen
Model type: Discrete-event simulation, Compartmental differential equation model
ICER: LED microscopy: $29/DALY; same-day LED microscopy: $45/DALY; full Xpert: $169/DALY; others dominated
Reporting of uncertainty: Table of DSA, Tornado diagram of DSA, Probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA), CEAC, 95% credible intervals
Main findings: We have assessed the effect of several promising tuberculosis diagnostic options that are being considered by many national tuberculosis programmes, and have identified three cost-effective strategies in the context of Tanzania: full rollout of Xpert MTB/RIF (B1), followed by same-day LED fluorescence microscopy (A3) and LED fluorescence microscopy(A2).

Population: Patients with sore throat
Compared strategies: Current standard of care; strep throat POC testing
ICER: -18.66 (province AB); -14.86 (province BC); -12.78 (province NS); -12.47 (province ON); -24.36 (province SK) costs or savings /patient
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA)
Main findings: This analysis estimates that in a scenario where 60% of patients with severe sore throat seek care in a community pharmacy, compared to a scenario where all patients seek care through a family physician, walk-in clinic or emergency room, the healthcare systems in the five provinces saves a mean of $12.47 to $24.36 per patient.

Population: Unvaccinated children coming to a physician's office with age-appropriate symptoms of uncomplicated ILI
Compared strategies: No antiviral treatment; rapid testing for influenza, followed by oseltamivir if results are positive; empiric oseltamivir treatment
ICER: $25,900 to $71,200/QALY, depending on age, compared with the no oseltamivir treatment strategy
Reporting of uncertainty: Table of DSA, Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied), CEAC
Main findings: This analysis demonstrates that when seasonal influenza viruses are circulating in the community and antiviral treatment is clinically indicated, empiric oseltamivir treatment of children who are suspected to have influenza illness may be a cost-effective treatment strategy.

Population: Adult, HIV-negative patients with presumptive/pulmonary TB
Compared strategies: Sputum smear microscopy; Xpert; Truenat; Truenat POC
ICER: Truenat POC: 210 /LYG, which dominated all other strategies
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA), Two-way sensitivity analysis graph
Main findings: Truenat, when replacing smear microscopy and used at point-of-care, increases the number of TB cases correctly detected and linked to care by 590 per 10,000 individuals with presumptive TB. It also increases life expectancy by nearly 0.4 years and is cost-effective

Population: Adults (16 years and older) and children (up to 15 years old).
Compared strategies: Observation only (reference strategy); clinical scoring; RDT testing; throat culture; clinical scoring combined with RDT testing; RDT testing combined with throat culture; systematic antibiotic therapy.
Included treatment: Amoxicillin penicillin A (6 days) and in case of allergy cefuroxime-axetil (4 days).
ICER: 970 in children and at 903in adults cost per suppurative complication avoided
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA), Tornado diagram of DSA
Main findings: The use of RDT was the most cost-effective strategy from the insurance perspective private US, while the use of culture appeared to be more efficient from the perspective of the system public Medicaid. In acute tonsillitis, in both adults and children, RDT testing by practitioners is the more efficient strategy to identify and treat patients with GAS tonsillitis. Combining RDT testing with throat culture can provide additional effectiveness, but at the cost of a significant extra charge for the community.

Setting: Multiple interacting components (laboratory, public health and clinical services)
Population: Population of England, taking into consideration the age distribution of the population and medium TB incidence
Compared strategies: National TB strain typing service
Included treatment: Latent infection treatment (rifampicin, isoniazid, pyridoxine); management of active disease (rifater, ethambutol, rifanah, pyridoxine)
ICER: ₤95,628/QALY (LTBI detecting increase from 3% to 4%); ₤54,539/QALY (LTBI detecting increase from 3% to 13%); cost-saving if diagnostic delay was reduced with 1 week
Reporting of uncertainty: Table of DSA, Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied)
Main findings: This analysis failed to demonstrate that the TB-STS is a cost-effective use of NHS resources. It suggests that it is unlikely that earlier identification of false positive cases related to laboratory contamination, or increases in the identification and prophylactic treatment of contacts with a latent infection could, on their own, justify the cost of the system.

Country/countries: Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia, South Africa, and Swaziland
Population: General population (with dynamic model). For TB diagnosis patients presenting to a health facility with suspected TB
Compared strategies: Current diagnostic algorithms; implementing Xpert in accordance with current WHO recommendations
ICER: $784/DALY; $810/life-year saved
Reporting of uncertainty: Table of DSA, Tornado diagram of DSA, Three-way sensitivity analysis graph, CEAC, uncertainty interval (2.5 and 97.5 percentiles)
Main findings: Along with the projected health benefits of scaling up Xpert will come significantly increased demands on healthcare resources. The large increase in funding required under the Xpert scenario raises the question of affordability. Although our cost-effectiveness results suggest that the introduction of Xpert represents good value for money according to typical international benchmarks, it does not automatically follow that TB program budgets will be able toabsorb these changes.

Population: Patients with suspected sepsis on the ICU and patients hospitalized with LRTI.
Compared strategies: Standard care; PCT-guided care
Time horizon: The length of the hospital stay
ICER: The incremental savings per antibiotic day avoided were -$584 for the PCT group
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA), Tornado diagram of DSA
Main findings: Using a Procalcitonin-algorithm to guide antibiotic use in sepsis and hospitalised lower respiratory tract infection patients is expected to generate cost-savings to the hospital and lower rates of antibiotic resistance and C.difficile infections.

Population: Two hypothetical cohorts were modeled in separate trial-based analyses: adults with ARTIs judged by their physicians to require antibiotics and all adults with ARTIs.
Compared strategies: Procalcitonin-guided antibiotic therapy; usual care.
Time horizon: ARTI treatment episode as the time horizon
ICER: 149 / antibiotic prescription saved
Reporting of uncertainty: Probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA), Cost-effectiveness acceptability curve(s)
Main findings: Procalcitonin testing is unlikely to be preferred over usual care when costs alone are considered, but is likely to be cost-effective when the costs of antibiotic resistance are considered and the test is used only in adults with ARTIs judged to require antibiotics by their physicians.

Population: Patients with presumptive TB
Compared strategies: A smear/culture-based algorithm; an Xpert-based algorithm
ICER: $6274 per additional MDR-TB case diagnosed
Main findings: The introduction of the Xpert-based algorithm has resulted in substantial increases in cost which are in line with modelling exercises undertaken in South Africa. However these were not matched by an increase in TB diagnostic efficacy; massive cost increases persist even when temporal trends of a possible declining TB prevalence were taken into consideration. One of the benefits of the Xpert-based algorithm was the modest increase in the number of MDR-TB cases diagnosed, which comes at high cost.

Population: Children presenting with ILI
Compared strategies: Rapid multiplex PCR; traditional PCR; direct-fluorescentantibody staining; 4: rapid antigen tests.
ICER: PCR: $115,556/QALY in children aged 3-36 months, and $228,000/QALY in children aged 3-18 yrs (other alternatives were dominated)
Reporting of uncertainty: Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied), CEAC
Main findings: A rapid multiplex PCR strategy was not only the most effective strategy in terms of maximizing patient QALYs, but was also the most expensive.

Population: Adults in the general U.S. population.
Compared strategies: Observation without testing or treatment; empirical treatment with penicillin; throat culture using a two-plate selective culture technique; optical immunoassay (OIA) followed by culture to confirm negative OIAtest results; OIA alone.
Included treatment: Penicillin at a dosage of 250 mg four times a day for 10 days.
ICER: Culture strategy: 0.2668 quality-adjusted life-day lost and an average cost of $6.66 per patient
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA), Probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA)
Main findings: Although the other four strategies had similar effectiveness (all resulted in about 0.27 lost quality-adjusted life-day), culture was the least expensive strategy.

Population: People presenting to medical admissions units, or any ward accepting acute medical admissions, with an acute exacerbation of chronic cardiopulmonary illness of ≤ 168 hours’ (7 days’) duration or an acute cardiopulmonary illness of ≤ 7 days’ duration
Compared strategies: Point-of-care tests (POCTs) for influenza A and B and pneumococcal infection; reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) tests for influenza A and B and RSV A and B; and conventional culture for these pathogens.
Included treatment: Broad-spectrum antibiotics (cephalosporins, co-amoxiclav, piperacillin with tazobactam, carbapenems, quinolones, tetracyclines, cotrimoxazole, clarithromycin, azithromycin and clindamycin); narrow-spectrum antibiotics (Gram-positive antibiotics benzylpenicillin, flucloxacillin, amoxicillin (and ampicillin), erythromycin, vancomycin, rifampicin, fusidic acid, linezolid, daptomycin, gram-negative antibiotics, gentamicin and other aminoglycosides, aztreonam, trimethoprim, nitrofurantoin, anaerobic antibiotics and metronidazole).
Clinical outcomes: QALYs, EQ-5D; proportion of patients who are prescribed antibiotics; time to treatment
ICER: 734717 per QALY
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA), Table of DSA, Probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA), Cost-effectiveness plane of PSA, Cost-effectiveness acceptability curve(s)
Main findings: The total costs and QALYs of each diagnostic strategy were similar, although, incrementally, PCR was the most cost-effective strategy. The analysis does not support routine use of point-of-care tests for either influenza or pneumococcal antigen for adults presenting with acute cardiopulmonary conditions, but suggests that conventional viral culture for clinical diagnosis should be replaced by PCR.

Population: Quebec (Canada) population
Compared strategies: Current care; potential rapid POC test
Model type: Dynamic deterministic compartmental models, Agent-level Markov model (SPLMM)
ICER: $7573 saved /100,000 person years and 1.92 life-years saved /100,000 person years
Reporting of uncertainty: Tornado diagram of DSA, CEAC
Main findings: Considering the baseline values of sensitivity, specificity, and cost to be 74%, 99%, and $25, respectively, for a POC test; the antiviral treatment based on this test appears dominant as compared to empirical antiviral treatment based on clinical judgment.

Population: Children (1 month to 15 years) visiting the pediatric emergency department of a hospital with meningeal signs
Compared strategies: Practice a lumbar puncture, based on the characteristics of the patient’s history, physical examination and serum C-reactive protein (CRP) ; do not practice this
ICER: € 401,965 per QALY (Streptococcus pneumoniae) and €22,635 per QALY (Neisseria meningitidis)
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA)
Main findings: Minimizing lumbar punctures and empirical treatments using a diagnostic decision rule, without missing a single case of meningitis, was a dominant strategy to actual practice.
Cost-effectiveness verdict: Cost-effective, not generalizable for vaccination strategies.

Population: 360 children from one month up to fifteen years of age visiting the emergency department of a hospital with meningeal signs between 1988 and 1998
Compared strategies: Diagnostic decision rule, based on a clinical score and a CSF score (cell count in cerebrospinal fluid) for lumbar puncture and empirical treatment for bacterial meningitis; current practice (a low threshold to perform a lumbar puncture, and empirical treatment)
ICER: Total costs current practice €2.976; total costs decision rule €2.684
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA)
Main findings: The decision rule reduced total costs by 292 euros per patient, 33 euros in the diagnostic phase and 259 euros in the treatment course.The application of the decision rule reduced the number of patients hospitalized.

Population: Patients aged ≥18 years presenting to their GP for the first time with an acute or worsened cough as the main or dominant symptom for up to 28 days, or who had a clinical presentation suggesting lower respiratory tract infections.
Compared strategies: Rapid test, point-of-care C-reactive protein.
Clinical outcomes: QALYs, Days free from disease, EQ-5D, symptom information (case report forms).
ICER: €112,7 / antibiotic prescription saved
Reporting of uncertainty: Cost-effectiveness acceptability curve(s)
Main findings: Patients receiving POCCRP did not have significantly different measures of recovery or outcomes compared to patients not receiving this test.
Cost-effectiveness verdict: Cost-effective, reduces the rate of antibiotic prescribing.

Country/countries: Belgium, United Kingdom, Netherlands, Poland and Spain
Population: Patients presenting with respiratory tract infections in primary care, from Belgium, the Netherlands, Poland, Spain and the UK (England and Wales).
Compared strategies: CRP; communication skills; CRP and communication skills combined; usual care
ICER: Communication skills was associated with an ICER of €68.08 per percentage reduction in antibiotic prescribing when compared with usual care. The ICER for CRP compared with communication skills was €176.53 and the ICER for the combined intervention compared with CRP was €338.89
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA), Probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA), Cost-effectiveness plane of PSA, Cost-effectiveness acceptability curve(s)
Main findings: In terms of cost per percentage reduction in antibiotic prescribing, overall, communication skills was the most cost-effective intervention. Similarly, the CUA also showed that communication skills was the most cost-effective intervention.

Population: Immunocompetent patients in the intensive care unit
Compared strategies: Empiric treatment only; quantitative nonprotected endotracheal cultures; bronchoscopy; nonbronchoscopic mini-bronchoalveolar lavage (mini-BAL)
ICER: No. of Initial Antibiotics: Zero: Empiric=Na; Empiric + ETT asp=72847; Empiric + mini-BAL=101479; Empiric + FOB=433261; One antibiotic: Empiric=Na; Empiric + ETT asp=20734; Empiric + mini-BAL=86184; Empiric + FOB=634288; Two antibiotics:Empiric + ETT asp=NA; Empiric + mini-BAL=4854; Empiric + FOB=819710; Empiric=dominated; Three antibiotics: Empiric + mini-BAL=NA; Empiric + ETT asp= dominated; Empiric + FOB= 1375978; Empiric= Dominated
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA), Two-way sensitivity analysis graph, Three-way (or more) sensitivity analysis graph, Probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA)
Main findings: From the perspective of minimizing cost, minimizing antibiotic use, and maximizing survival, the best strategy was three antibiotics with mini-BAL.

Population: 372 patients over 15 years of age who were referred for a sore throat were included between March 1999 and September 2001 if their clinical score was between two and four points.
Compared strategies: Rapid test systematique then antibiotic therapy if the test is positive; quick test if the score is 2 or 3 then antibiotic to patients with a positive result or a clinical basis of 4; empiric antibiotic therapy to patients with a clinical score of 3 or 4.
Clinical outcomes: Rate of appropriate use of an antibiotic per patients treated
ICER: $15.30 (rapid test strategy) per patient
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA)
Main findings: The results of this study is that the rapid test is a valid method for the diagnosis of GABHS. The best clinical strategy for the diagnosis and treatment of pharyngitis in adults is the rapid systematic test in patients with a clinical population greater than or equal to two.

Population: Presumptive TB patients undergoing an initial consultation
Compared strategies: Standard of care (presumptive TB patients undergoing an initial consultation, a chest X-ray, two SSM examinations and HIV testing, those with HIV co-infection undergo culture and DST); SSM testing of two samples was replaced by Xpert testing of one sputum sample
Included treatment: The WHO-recommended standard first-line drug regimen
ICER: $943 per additional TB diagnosis;  US$356 per additional TB diagnosis with bacteriological confirmation
Reporting of uncertainty: Table of DSA, Tornado diagram of DSA, Two-way sensitivity analysis graph, PSA: uncertainty ranges
Main findings: Xpert is more costly than SSM, but has been shown to be more accurate, and potentially more costeffective in low and high-burden countries with high MDR-TB and HIV co-infection rates. In a setting with low MDR-TB and moderate HIV coinfection rates such as Brazil, implementation of single-sample Xpert testing replacing two-sample SSM tests would result in a modest increase (US$1.2 million per year, or 1.7% of Brazil’s NTP budget) in total health system costs for the additional TB confirmation of 3344 patients.

Population: Patients with presumptive tuberculosis
Compared strategies: Same-day smear microscopy; POC Xpert
ICER: Incremental costs per clinical outcome: diagnosed by index test: 4186; starting treatment: 1464; starting treatment same day: 561; completing treatment: 1211; improved morbidity: 1918
Reporting of uncertainty: Tornado diagram of DSA, Cost-effectiveness acceptability curve(s)
Main findings: Point-of-care Xpert is likely to be cost-effective in settings willing to pay at least $4500 per treatment initiation or $3800 per treatment completion among culture-positive patients

Population: Patients 12 months of age and younger who were admitted  for acute bronchiolitis
Compared strategies: “good practice”, which included adherance to diagnosis guidelines (including: hemogram, C‐reactive protein, procalcitonin, chest radiography, and tests for detection of respiratory viruses); "bad practice"
Included treatment: Inhaled or nebulized beta 2 agonists, inhaled or nebulized anticholinergics, nebulized epinephrine, inhaled corticosteroids, systemic corticosteroids, antibiotics, and nebulized hypertonic saline
ICER: "Good practice" was dominant
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA), Tornado diagram of DSA
Main findings: Compared with lack of “good practice,” the utilization of “good practice” in the diagnosis and management of patients with bronchiolitis was associated with both fewer patients readmitted within 10 days of post discharge (0.88 vs 0.99 on average per patient) and lower costs (US$1529.3 versus $1709.1 average cost perpatient), thus leading to dominance

Population: Unvaccinated, healthy, working adults aged 20-50, presenting with influenza-like illness during the influenza season
Compared strategies: No diagnostic test; Directigen (influenza A/B); FLU OIA; QuickVue; ZstatFlu
Included treatment: Amantadine; rimantadine; oseltamivir; zanmivir; azithromicin; amoxicillin
ICER: All testing strategies are dominated by empiric treatment with amantadine
Reporting of uncertainty: DSA
Main findings: The economic impact alone validates the use of antiviral therapy in healthy adults with influenza-like illness. The small benefit of shortening symptoms by an average of 1 day is by no means trivial.

Population: Persons aged >65 years, presenting with influenza symptoms during the influenza season
Compared strategies: Current care; Quickvue
ICER: Amantadine treatment only: $1129/QALY; test-treat oseltamivir: $5025/QALY, empiric oseltamivir: $10,296/QALY, other test-treat combinations (extended) dominated
Reporting of uncertainty: Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied), Two-way sensitivity analysis graph, PSA
Main findings: Under most circumstances, antiviral therapy is reasonably cost-effective and within the range of other widely accepted interventions for older adults. The optimal strategy, however, depends on the patient’s vaccination status, the probability that he or she has influenza, and the risk for hospitalization

Population: Healthy children at ages 2, 7 and 15 years
Compared strategies: Quickvue; ZstatFlu
ICER: Antiviral therapy: $800 - $1800/QALY; testing stategies were dominated in most scenarios
Reporting of uncertainty: Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied), PSA
Main findings: During local influenza outbreaks, children with symptoms of ILI benefit from antiviral therapy if it is initiated within 48 hours of symptom onset. At the same time, antiviral therapy saves money if parents return to work sooner. In that case, there is no trade-off between cost and effectiveness.
Cost-effectiveness verdict: Testing not cost-effective - empirical treatment is cost-effective

Population: The patient population in this study is patients with suspected ARIinfection diagnoses seen in one of three settings: inpatient hospitalsetting (not in the intensive care unit - ICU); hospital ICU; outpatient clinic or emergency department (ED) based on the meta-analysis data
Compared strategies: PCT testing and monitoring; usual care
Included treatment: Typical dosages and mix of expected therapy were derived frompublished clinical treatment guidelines (many references, but nothing explicit)
ICER: The costs of PCT-guided care for the one million member cohort was $2,083,545, compared to $2,780,332 for the usual care group, resulting in net savings of nearly $700,000 costs or savings /patient
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA), Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied)
Main findings: The results show substantial savings associated with the use of PCT to guide antibiotic treatment of ARI in common US treatment settings. Across all three settings PCT-guided care is associated with net savings ranging from $73,326 in the ICU to  > $5 million in the outpatient clinic and ED setting, for total savings to the IDN of more than $6 million.

Population: Healthy working adults younger than 65 years of age who consult within 2 days of the onset of influenza-like symptoms
Compared strategies: No zanamivir; test with zanamivir; systematic zanamivir
ICER: test: $-14.40 for 0.65 averted influenza days; empiric treatment: $-29.80 for 0.81 averted influenza day (1)
Reporting of uncertainty: Table of DSA, Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied)
Main findings: During influenza epidemics, when unvaccinated healthy working adults consult within 2 days of the onset of influenza-like symptoms, systematic zanamivir prescription without rapid influenza test is a dominant strategy from a societal perspective.

Population: HIV-infected individuals presenting with signs/symptoms of active TB disease
Compared strategies: ZN smear-microscopy testing of two sputa; same as 1 plus one urine sample for point-of-care LF-LAM testing; Xpert on one sputum (rifampin resistance is confirmed with conventional culture and DST for all patients); same as 3 plus one urine sample for point-of-care LF-LAM testing
Included treatment: TB treatment; TB treatment category 2; MDR-TB treatment; Annual HIV care costs
ICER: ZN microscopy + urine sample testing: $33/DALY; Xpert on one sputum: $58/DALY; Xpert on one sputum + urine sample testing: $57/DALY (ZN microscopy as reference)
Reporting of uncertainty: Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied), CEAC
Main findings: Compared with an algorithm of Xpert testing alone, the combination of Xpert with LFLAM was considered highly cost-effective. Addition of urine LF-LAM testing to smear-microscopy was a less effective strategy than Xpert replacement of smear-microscopy, but was less costly and also considered highly cost-effective compared with continued usage of smear-microscopy alone.

Population: Children aged 18 years or below with ILI, had symptoms and signs compatible with influenza.
Compared strategies: No antiviral therapy; 2: post influenza RDT treatment; 3: empiric treatment
Reporting of uncertainty: Tornado diagram of DSA, cost-effectiveness plane
Main findings: The empiric oseltamivir treatment of children who are suspected to have influenza illness may be a dominant or a very cost-effective treatment strategy in comparison against post RIDT treatment with oseltamivir and no antiviral therapy.

Population: Patients presenting with ILI
Compared strategies: Do not treat with antiviral drugs; treat all patients with antiviral drugs; test then treat those who test positive
ICER: For stockpiling: ₤1900 and ₤13700/QALY for the 1918 and 1957/69 scenarios; test-treat ₤31000 and ₤228000/QALY
Reporting of uncertainty: Tornado diagram of DSA, Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied), cost-effectiveness plane
Main findings: Near-patient testing is unlikely to be a cost-effective approach to conserving AV stocks but might be considered early in a pandemic. A more cost-effectivestrategy would be to increase the stockpile of AV drugs.

Population: 32-year old patients with typical influenza symptoms and a temperature 37.8°C during an influenza season. Other age categories in sensitivity analysis.
Compared strategies: No antiviral testing or treatment; oseltamivir/zanamivir treatment without testing; empiric rimantadine; empiric amantadine; test-treat oseltamivir/zanamivir; 6: test-treat rimantadine; 7: test-treat amantadine
ICER: Empiric amantadine: $9.06 per illness day avoided; empiric oseltamivir: $198 per illness day avoided; other strategies (extended) dominated
Reporting of uncertainty: Tornado diagram of DSA, CEAC
Main findings: Amantadine, zanamivir, and oseltamivir cost about $250 or less per quality-adjusted day gained or illness day avoided for patients with fever and typical influenza symptoms. Rapid testing was, forthe most part, more costly and less effective than treatment without testing.

Population: Patients presenting to care for TB diagnosis
Compared strategies: Centralized Xpert; decentralized Xpert
Included treatment: Unspecified treatment for sensitive and resistant TB
ICER: 3161 /DALY
Reporting of uncertainty: Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied), Cost-effectiveness acceptability curve(s)
Main findings: Provided that decentralized testing can be performed with equal quality as centralized testing, the costs and LTFU incurred by using a hub-and-spoke system are likely to justify the increased costs of decentralized testing, except in settings where testing volumes is low.

Population: One hundred patient were evaluated for criteria meeting the subjective diagnostic criteria for chronic rhinosinusitis as developed by the Task Force for Acute and Chronic Rhinosinusitis
Compared strategies: Subjective-based diagnosis; diagnosed with a screening CT scan.
ICER: 147 per patient
Reporting of uncertainty: NA
Main findings: With screening CT scanning, patients are diagnosed more accurately, according to whether they have disease or not. This is important because the current subjective method of diagnosis of chronic rhinosinusitis is inaccurate.

Population: Patients with suspected ARI infection diagnoses seen in one of three settings (subgroups): (1) inpatient hospital setting (not in the ICU); (2) hospital ICU; (3) outpatient clinic or emergency department (ED).
Compared strategies: Usual care; PCT testing and monitoring
ICER: In the inpatient setting, the costs of PCT-guided care compared to usual care resulted in net savings of 721,563 CNY Chinese hospital system; In the ICU and outpatient settings, savings were 250,699 CNY and 2.4 million CNY, respectively. The overall annual net savings of PCT-guided care was nearly 3.4 million CNY
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA)
Main findings: Our results demonstrate substantial savings associated with the use of PCT to guide antibiotic treatment of ARI across common China treatment settings.

Setting: Public sector clinics and private clinics
Population: Individuals are followed from birth to death, TB suspects for TB diagnosis
Compared strategies: current standard of care; Xpert for DST; Xpert for initial diagnoses and DST in public clinics; PPM; PPM combined with GeneXpert for DST; PPM combined with GeneXpert for initial diagnoses and DST in public clinics
ICER: PPM: $72/QALY; PPM + Xpert: 145/QALY; PPM + Xpert in public clinics: 1104/QALY (others dominated)
Reporting of uncertainty: CEAC, partly PSA (on the simultaneous effect of uncertainty about the quality of life lost due to TB and the costs of care)
Main findings: Our results illustrate that there is no silver bullet for combating the TB epidemic -- introducing rapid and accurate diagnostic systems, either for initial diagnosis or DST, will have limited ability to control the epidemic and, in a context where PPM is available, is not cost-effective if implemented without substantial effort to bring the fragmented public and private treatment systems together.

Population: Adults presenting with suspected active TB
Compared strategies: QFT-GIT; TSPOT.TB; reference standard (minimum set of tests defined by the NICE guideline, verified by a panel of blinded clinicians)
ICER: Varying from 6640 to 22010 /QALY
Reporting of uncertainty: Cost-effectiveness plane of PSA, Cost-effectiveness acceptability curve(s)
Main findings: The use of current IGRA tests for ruling out active TB would be unlikely to be considered cost-effective if a QALY were to be valued at £20,000 or £30,000. There are cost savings, but the health detriment is large because of the delay in diagnosing active TB.

Population: ILI patients
Compared strategies: Influenza clinical prediction tool; targeted rapid influenza testing; universal rapid influenza testing
ICER: The incremental cost per antibiotic prescription avoided with clinical prediction versus standard care was US$3.0, which was lower than the base-case estimate of the cost of antimicrobial resistance per ILI antibiotic prescription (US$12.5)
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA), Probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA)
Main findings: Standard care was less expensive than other strategies across all parameter values in one-way sensitivity analyses. To obtain a cost-effectiveness ratio lower than US$12.5 with targeted testing versus standard care, the test price must be <US$2.6. At a higher threshold of US$28.7, the test price must be <US$7.7.

Population: Children and adolescents presenting with pharyngitis.
Compared strategies: Observe without testing or treatment; treat all suspected cases with antibiotics; treat those with positive throat cultures; treat those with positive rapid tests; treat those with positive rapid tests and those with positive throat cultures after negative rapid tests; use a clinical scoring measure to determine the diagnosis/treatment strategy.
ICER: $32,132.01 rapid antigen testing had the best cost-utility. It dominated both "treat all" and "rapid test + culture" strategies
Reporting of uncertainty: Table of DSA, Tornado diagram of DSA, Probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA)
Main findings: When the cost of a culture is low, in comparison with a paid test, culturing samples for all children may be the best option. As the cost of throat cultures increase, relative to the price of a rapid test, the rapid test becomes the better option.

Population: individuals with prolonged (>2 weeks) cough and/or other TB symptoms, presenting at a primary care clinic
Compared strategies: Smear plus culture; Xpert
ICER: Cost savings of $3.28 per valid Xpert result
Main findings: The cost per Xpert was only US$1.88 higher than the cost for smear microscopy and culture, and US$14.05 higher than smear microscopy only. Due to the low error rate, the cost per valid Xpert result was US$3.28 lower than the cost per valid smear microscopy plus culture result. The cost per case diagnosed was similar for both strategies (US$266 vs. US$260).

Population: Individuals suspected of having TB
Compared strategies: Two sputum microscopy, followed by clinical diagnosis that might include chest Xray and antibiotic trial; Xpert after two negative smear examinationss; Xpert instead of smear examination
Included treatment: Specified treatment protocol of TB treatment, also including what to to if resistance is found
ICER: Xpert after two negative smear examinations: India: $55/DALY, South Africa: $110/DALY, Uganda: $41/DALY; Xpert instead of smear examination: India: $68/DALY, South Africa: $138/DALY, Uganda: $37/DALY
Reporting of uncertainty: Table of DSA, Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied), Three-way  sensitivity analysis graph, CEAC
Main findings: Our results suggest that Xpert is likely to be more cost-effective than a base case of smear microscopy and clinical diagnosis of smear-negative TB.

Population: The study population comprised adult HIV-infected patients older than 18 years, with presumptive active pulmonary TB
Compared strategies: Microscopic observation drug susceptibility (MODS) assay; Xpert MTB/Rif test.
ICER: MODS: $34 per TB patient diagnosed; Xpert: $71 per TB patient diagnosed
Reporting of uncertainty: Table of DSA, Tornado diagram of DSA
Main findings: The algorithm using MODS was more cost-effective compared to the algorithm using Xpert for a wide range of different values of accuracy, cost and TB prevalence. The cost (threshold value), where the algorithm using Xpert was optimal over the algorithm using MODS was $5.92

Population: Pulmonary and extrapulmonary TB suspect patients
Compared strategies: Single vs. repeated Xpert assay
ICER: Pulmonary: 467.72; extrapulmonary: 291.87 per additional TB diagnosis
Reporting of uncertainty: NA
Main findings: The cost-effectiveness analysis showed that the incremental cost of performing a second Xpert was very high for the smear-positive TB patients

Population: TB suspects
Compared strategies: Sputum smear microscopy (SM, base case); Xpert replacing SM; Xpert after smear-negative SM; microscopic observation drug-susceptibility (MODS) as a replacement; MODS as an add-on for smear-negative SM
ICER: SM + MODS: $5648/DALY;  MODS: $5375/DALY; SM + Xpert: $346/DALY; Xpert: $122/DALY
Reporting of uncertainty: Tornado diagram of DSA, Probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA), CE plane
Main findings: Our results suggest that in this rural African setting substituting SM by Xpert MTB/RIF would be the most cost-effective strategy compared to its implementation as an add-on strategy or MODS implementation. However, the degree of uncertainty is high.

Population: Hospitalized community acquired pneumoniae
Compared strategies: BinaxNow-SP and culture; culture alone
Included treatment: Ceftriaxone plus azithromycin for empirical treatment; penicillin G for tretment of SP
ICER: Incremental cost per patient 36 dollars. Incremental costs per case correctly classified 582 dollars
Reporting of uncertainty: Deterministic sensitivity analysis (DSA)
Main findings: An overall increase in diagnostic accuracy of 6.2% due to the addition of BinaxNOW‐SP.

Population: Patients with a cough of at least 2 weeks and two negative smears
Compared strategies: Conventional diagnostic algorithm (based on clinical findings, radiological features and an antibiotic trial); culture-based algorithm that uses TLA and LJ cultures in addition to the conventional algorithm
ICER: Varying between €452-€3121 per case depending on exact algoritm used
Reporting of uncertainty: DSA
Main findings: Using TLA/LJ in addition to the conventional algorithm made it more expensive, although its cost-effectiveness would improve if the number of screened patients increased. The decision to adopt rapid culture for TB epends on the government/community’s willingness to pay for it.
Cost-effectiveness verdict: culture-based algorithm may be hard to afford for resource-limited countries

Population: Adult patients hospitalized for severe respiratory infection, suspected of influenza
Compared strategies: Immunofluorescence assay; PCR testing; empirical antiviral treatment plus PCR, to later continue or discontinue treatment based on test result; empirical antiviral treatment
ICER: Empirical treatment dominates testing
Reporting of uncertainty: Two-way sensitivity analysis graph, CEAC
Main findings: In a season when the ‘seasonal influenza’ virus strains are predominant, ‘‘empirical antiviral treatment alone’’ would be a cost-effective option at influenza prevalence levels of 2.5% or above, whereas the ‘PCR guided treatment’ approach would be cost-effective at a low prevalence of less than 2.5%.

Population: Patients hospitalized for suspected active pulmonary TB
Compared strategies: Conventional approach; smear plus Xpert (for smear-negative); Xpert
Included treatment: Early treatment; late treatment; both split up in first- and second line (based on whether or not multi-drug resistant)
Clinical outcomes: Both single- and synthesis-based(for different diagnostic strategies)
ICER: $99/QALY
Reporting of uncertainty: Sensitivity analysis graph (with one parameter varied), CEAC
Main findings: Using a simple sputum test of Xpert at inital assessment was the most cost-effective option

Population: Elderly patients with ILI
Compared strategies: Clinical judgement without testing; rapid molecular POCT
Reporting of uncertainty: Table of DSA, Tornado diagram of DSA, cost-effectiveness plane, CEAC
Main findings: The expected ICER of POCT-PCR is SD29,582, lower than 1x GDP per capita of Hong Kong (USD43,497). The base-case ICER is therefore highly cost-effective from the perspective of healthcare provider in Hong Kong.
